Articles.Content:
Can someone explain the rules for managing science data?  I made a satellite/probe with multiple science gadgets on it and sent it on an orbit of Ike.  then I sent it back up to the main vehicle I used to get everything from kerbin to duna/ike.  So I sent over a kerbal, collected all the data from the probe and returned to the vehicle.  When i tried to board, it says that it would have to dump a bunch of my data.  I don't understand.  Is there a limit to the amount of data that can be stored on different capsules?

And why can there only be ONE crew report for each misson?  how is it that I can get different data by taking a crew report over different biomes, but I can only keep one at a time?

I understand why material bays and goo canisters can only be used once, but why it it the same for thermometers/barometers?

Hello,

You only can have one experiment in one location at time in a capsule. In other word, you can have as much as you want one experiment in a pod as long as it has been run in different location of each other present in the pod. (exemple: you can have two crew report in the same capsule if one is low in space and the other is high in space.)

I use the [x] science mod to help me to manage experiment I run in a place. (But I limit to unlocked experiment only (to not spoil the game (biome of other bodies, new experiment I don't have yet...))

Vive_moi

EDIT: the only part that can handle many of the same experiment in the same place is the MPL.

Edited February 19, 2016 by Vive_moi

22 minutes ago, Perotis said:

Can someone explain the rules for managing science data?  I made a satellite/probe with multiple science gadgets on it and sent it on an orbit of Ike.  then I sent it back up to the main vehicle I used to get everything from kerbin to duna/ike.  So I sent over a kerbal, collected all the data from the probe and returned to the vehicle.  When i tried to board, it says that it would have to dump a bunch of my data.  I don't understand.  Is there a limit to the amount of data that can be stored on different capsules?

There's effectively no limit.  Or rather, there is a limit, but it's one that's not much of a limit in practice.

A command pod can store only one copy of any given science result.  A science result is the combination of, 1. instrument, 2. celestial body, 3. biome, 4. situation.

Thus, for example, "temperature scan while flying over Kerbin's Highlands" is a science result.  This would be a different science result than if it was some other experiment (like "EVA report"), or some other celestial body (e.g. Duna), or some other biome (e.g. "Grasslands"), or some other situation (e.g. "landed").

As long as they're different results, you can store as many as you want in a pod.  You couldn't store two of "temperature scan while flying over Kerbin's Grasslands", but you could store one of those with, for example, "temperature scan while landed at Kerbin's Grasslands" or "temperature scan while flying over Kerbin's Shores".

That "can't have two of the same thing" limitation doesn't really matter much in practice, because you don't really get credit for more than one of them anyway.  Once you bring home a "Temperature scan while flying over Kerbin's Grasslands", you get a chunk of science points for that, and then bringing home another identical one of those doesn't give you anything.  (Well, actually it gives you a very small fraction of that, but it's such a tiny amount that it's generally not worth bothering with).

So basically, if you're trying to enter a command pod and it's warning you that you'll have to dump some results, that's fine:  it means you already have that same identical science in the pod so what your kerbal is carrying is just an extra (nearly worthless) copy.

Note that not all science experiments are per-biome for all situations.  Thus, for example, in "space near ___" situation, EVA results are per-biome, but Mystery Goo (for example) is not.  So if you're orbiting the Mun, say, and going over all the different biomes, you can repeatedly hop out of your pod to get different science results for "EVA report over Mun's <biome>"... but you can only get one Goo result, because it's just "goo observation from space near the Mun" and it doesn't matter what biome you're over.

29 minutes ago, Perotis said:

And why can there only be ONE crew report for each misson?  how is it that I can get different data by taking a crew report over different biomes, but I can only keep one at a time?

Because it's meant to be transmitted.  Crew reports and EVA reports are the only science results that give you 100% credit when you transmit them-- you don't lose a percentage, like you do with other experiments.  So when you get a crew report, just go ahead and transmit it and then you have space for the next one.  There's no reason to hang on to it and physically bring it home.

 

30 minutes ago, Perotis said:

I understand why material bays and goo canisters can only be used once, but why it it the same for thermometers/barometers?

It's not.  You take a measurement, go EVA to pull the science out of 'em, enter your pod, take another measurement in a different biome or whatever.

Note that material bays and goo canisters can also be re-used multiple times, as long as you have a scientist present.  An EVA scientist can "restore" these by right-clicking on them, thus resetting them and making them ready to take another measurement.

45 minutes ago, Perotis said:

And why can there only be ONE crew report for each misson?  how is it that I can get different data by taking a crew report over different biomes, but I can only keep one at a time?

I understand why material bays and goo canisters can only be used once, but why it it the same for thermometers/barometers?

 

There is no limit to the number of crew reports. However, you can only have one "active" one at a time. Just as each instrument can only have one active report in it at a time.

However, if you EVA you can remove the reports from the pod, and when you do that it will also convert the crew report into an ordinary report. Then you jump back into the pod and you can do another crew report. Magic!

So I ran 4 goo experiments that all gave me science  and the same for 4 temp and pressure experiments.  but when I collect the data and board the capsule it only gave me the science from 2 goo 1 temp and 1 pres.

4 hours ago, Perotis said:

So I ran 4 goo experiments that all gave me science  and the same for 4 temp and pressure experiments.  but when I collect the data and board the capsule it only gave me the science from 2 goo 1 temp and 1 pres.

That probably means that a bunch of them were duplicates.  What were the results you collected?

That is, for each one, what was the experiment, the celestial body, the biome, and the situation?

In other words, for example, if you too four temperature measurements, fill this in:

  1. I took the temperature at <planet> in <biome> and <situation>
  2. I took the temperature at <planet> in <biome> and <situation>
  3. I took the temperature at <planet> in <biome> and <situation>
  4. I took the temperature at <planet> in <biome> and <situation>

If all four of those were the same planet, same biome, and same situation, then they're gonna collapse down to a single result because they're all duplicates.

The wiki page on science at http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Science is actually quite good (and exhaustive), particularly the table in the section "Possible combinations of Activity, Situation, and Biome".

So if you look at the Goo column, for example, you can see that you for "Surface: Landed" or "Surface: Splashed Down", you can get a different science report from each biome. However, from "Flying Low" upwards, the reports are "global", meaning that you can only get one result from each body (i.e. one from Kerbin, one from the Mun, etc.). That means the Goo can give you one report low in the atmosphere, one high in the atmosphere, one in near space and one in high orbit. Since Kerbin's moons have no atmosphere and no oceans, you get one per biome landed, plus one in near space and one in high space.

Again, from that table, you can see that temperature measurements are slightly better: they are biome-specific for "Flying Low" but become global from "Flying High" upwards. Good for Kerbin, but no better than Goo for its moons (again, no atmosphere so no "flying" possible).

So as Snark pointed out in the previous post, there is no point making multiple observations if they are of the same place.

Finally, you should be aware that each report will show a certain number of science points even if you already have a copy with you. The report's credits only change to show you have already done it once you have actually retrieved the data back at KSC.
